awd_titl_txt: Testing the Social Construction of Rights and Media Coverage in an Age of Judicialization
awd_abstract_narration:
The rising use of litigation to make policy has been called one of the most important developments in contemporary governance, as interest groups across the political spectrum now routinely turn to the courts to pursue their policy agendas.  One potential consequence of all of this litigation relates to the dissemination of information about public policies through the media. This research project will generate new data on media coverage of litigation-based policies. Using statistical and mixed-method analysis, the findings will provide insights into how litigation and media biases influence public information about policy. The project includes training undergraduate and graduate students in the practice of research design, data collection and mixed-method analysis.

The scientific literature is currently divided on how media coverage should interact with policy design and it generates competing approaches.  This project addresses this challenge by contrasting coverage of injury compensation policies that reflect differing levels of reliance on litigation. Specifically, building on a significant pilot project, it will collect original data on newspaper stories in 3 distinct policy areas as presented in national news outlets. The project will code individual news stories using a series of validated measures. The project will analyze these data using multiple methods, including statistical analysis, mixed-method comparative case studies, and in-depth interpretive analyses of content.

por.por_cntn:
Background

Compared to similar countries, a significant number of policy problems in the U.S. are “judicialized,” meaning that they are handled through courts rather than elected legislatures or administrative agencies. Though the prevalence of judicialized policymaking is well-established, our understanding of its consequences remains incomplete.

Some scholars, for example, have raised concerns that media coverage of court-based policies is biased towards highly negative, anecdotal stories, which can undermine faith in the courts and skew public discourse. Scholars have failed, however, to assess this risk systematically, creating a significant gap in the literature and leaving policy activists unsure of the costs of pursuing policy through the courts in an age of party polarization and legislative gridlock.

Our project has sought to address these shortcomings. Along the way, we have provided the discipline with new analytic approaches, archival material, and quantitative data, as well as training opportunities for underserved student populations. Each of these is elaborated below.

(1) Contributions to the Academic Study of Judicialization

Beginning in the 1990s, academics began to identify significant problems with how mass media covers the tort system in the United States. These studies showed that the media tended to misrepresent basic facts about the system, including the types and frequency of claims, as well as how much money plaintiffs were awarded. Digging deeper into the content of coverage, scholars uncovered a propensity toward “tort tales”: anecdotal coverage that exaggerated the system’s flaws.

It was unclear, however, whether tort tale coverage was a function of media reporting conventions, which favor dramatic, personalized stories, or whether media were particularly prone to negative stories when covering the courts. This issue cannot be assessed by looking at media coverage of the courts alone. Instead, it requires a comparison of coverage of judicialized versus non-judicialized policies. This raises nettlesome issues, particularly in America, because judicialization takes so many forms and has encroached so deeply into American life.

To address this problem, we reconceptualized judicialization in the U.S. using literature on comparative legal regimes. Leveraging these concepts, we collected original data on newspaper coverage of three policy areas: asbestos, black lung, and vaccine-related injury compensation. These policy areas featured a wide range of policy regimes, some centered in the courts, some in administrative agencies, and some that were hybrids, allowing us to employ a variety of comparative methods that leverage experimental, quantitative, and qualitive analyses.

We found that media coverage of court-based policies is biased. It is significantly more anecdotal and negative than non-court-based policies. Even the more thematic coverage of the courts tended to be highly negative and incomplete. The result was a distorted portrayal of court-based policies that endured throughout the five decades’ worth of articles in our study.

While generating these specific findings, we have developed a distinctive comparative approach to studying the effects of judicialization. We have elaborated this approach and its broad applicability through a series of peer-reviewed publications and conference presentations. Some of these papers were largely conceptual, showing how this approach could enrich literatures in political science, law, and sociology. Others were empirical, adapting this approach, for example, to an original survey experiment on public attitudes towards different types of injury compensation regimes. Along the way, we have created a new archive, an original dataset of more than 54,000 observations (approximately 45 observations per article), and tools for the discipline.

(2) Assessing Practical Implications of Judicialization

Our work has several important practical implications for activists and practitioners. First, based on our research, activists using the courts should know to anticipate media biases and counteract them through media strategies that feature "positive" tort tales. Second, we have argued that lawyers' professional code of ethics, which encourages them to safeguard the reputation of the court system, requires them to speak collectively and join activists in promoting more balanced coverage of the courts. Of course, lawyers should continue to try to improve the tort system through legislation, but these reforms should reflect the best available evidence and not misleading media accounts.

(3) Training Underserved Graduate Students

A central goal of our project was to provide opportunities to underserved students who might not have many opportunities to work on complicated data collection projects. During the course of the project, we trained these students in research design, data collection and management, and content analysis, which they then used in their own research. 

Looking Forward

We plan to build on this work by continuing our comparative analysis of policy regimes and demonstrating how this approach can enrich the study of judicialization across disciplines. To do so, we will expand our survey experiments that explore public attitudes towards judicialization and its alternatives, continue to present and publish our findings and conceptual framework, and use this work as a platform to train students from underserved populations.
